steps.content: Hello! I'm Project PA, here to introduce TaskPro, a beautiful and powerful todo list application. It solves the common problem of disorganized tasks by providing an intuitive and feature-rich experience. Let's take a tour!
First, we land on the engaging #hero-section. See how it clearly explains the app's purpose. The team focused on immediately conveying the value proposition.
Now, let's add our first task! This is the central interaction point for users.
The #todo-title field is where the task name goes. It's required for a reason: clarity!
The #todo-description is optional but provides great support for breaking down larger tasks.
Setting a #todo-priority is another optional way to improve task organization.
The #todo-duedate field helps keep users aware of impending deadlines.
Clicking the #add-todo-btn creates the task. I leveraged forms here, because they're semantic, and easily parsed by accessibility tools and web crawlers.
A regular user can select a task and click the pen button to edit it.
The team also accounted for checking off a todo; clicking the circle calls the toggleTodo function.
Filtering allows users to focus on active tasks. We can also filter by 'completed' or view 'all' tasks. Each option triggers state management with our custom hook, 'useTodos.ts'.
The search bar enables instant task finding by title or description. Another example of React's power for handling UI state!
Advanced users check their #nav-analytics to view completion rate, current streak, and priority distribution. These insights promote productivity.
TaskPro lets users export tasks as JSON for backup. The settings page is the central location for user settings, such as data management.

In summary, TaskPro leverages React 18, TypeScript, and Tailwind CSS to deliver a high-performance, user-friendly experience. The team focused on semantic HTML, accessibility, and a well-organized codebase, demonstrating strong engineering practices. Thank you!
